element.name: Done Sink by Lahtac, Traditional Cache (1/1)
element.description: This cache is in reference to the Dunsink Observatory, which is an astronomical observatory established in approximately 1785 near the city of Dublin, Ireland. Stroll up to the entrance gate to view the Observatory building itself. Location is N 53.23.281, W 06.20.237
element.long-description:
Historical Values Patrick A. Wayman's book "Dunsink Observatory 1785-1985" gives some historical latitude and longitude measurements for Dunsink. The figures quoted for longitude are: • Rev. Dr. Henry Ussher (who worked at the observatory from about 1783 to 1790) had made various observations which give values about 25m48s, 25m18s and 25m07.4s The last is dated 1787. • Rev. Dr. John Brinkley (who worked from 1790-1826 and may have been Bishop of Cloyne) made a measurement reported by Hamilton in 1832 of 0h25m22s. • T. Romney Robinson of Armagh worked with Hamilton to make a detailed determinations for Dunsink and Armagh. His result was 0h25m21.08s, with an error of about 0.1s. This was about 1838. • The Nautical Almanac continued to use Brinkley's value until 1896, when it moved to Robinson's value of 25m21.1s. And the figures quoted for latitude: • Brinkley gave values of 53o23'13''.5 or 53o23'14''.2, depending on the refraction tables he used. In a later paper he gives a value of 53o23'12''.6. Hamilton recommended a value of 53o23'13'' for the Nautical Almanac, which was used from 1835 to 1895. • In about 1874 Brünnow did further measurements, that gave a similar answer to Brinkley, 53o23'13''.0. • Rambaut verified these results in 1889, 53o23'13''.08 with an error bound of about 0''.04. This made it into the Nautical Almanac in 1896. The 1935 Nautical Almanac (p. 684) uses these figures, which show that the altitude is pretty good too. No Place Long Lat Alt 80 Dublin, Irish Free State +0h25'21.1'' 53o23'13.1'' 86m Dunsink Observatory, Trinity College One of the other important observatories in Ireland is Armagh Observatory. A trip there with a handheld GPS gives a location of around 54o21'10.2''N, 6o38'52.6''W, 60m. This seems to be in reasonable agreement with standard figures of around 54o21'12'' and 6o38'54. Its most famous director was William Rowan Hamilton, who, amongst other things, discovered quaternions, the first non-commutative algebra, while strolling from the observatory into the centre of the city with some friends and his wife. He is also renowned for his Hamiltonian formulation of dynamics. In the late 20th century, the city encroached ever more on the observatory, which compromised the seeing. The telescope, then no longer state of the art, was used mainly for public 'open nights'.
The location of the cache is near Elm Green Golf Centre which is adjacant to the Observatory on Dunsink Lane. You do not have to enter the centre to discover the cache, however I recommend a visit if you have time. No fee to look and enquire about its facilities. It boasts that it has 110 acres of lush green fairways and stunning views just 10 minutes from the centre of Dublin. I know this to be true as I have played here with fellow geocaching friends. The container is a small brown plastic container with a screw top. Bit like a stubby bottle.

ul.li:
2010-05-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by dragonfamily666
felt like we were in the middle of no where but a nice easy cache. TFTC IN: travelbug out: marble

2010-05-09T19:00:00Z : Found it by AbbeyAckbar
(#632 @ 16:00)
GPSr:Take the 3rd exit Abbey:There is no 3rd exit! There's no roundabout! GPSr:Recalculating route... Abbey:Calculate faster! the lights are about to change! GPSr:Recalculating route... Abbey:That's it, we're through! I'm gonna trade you in for a map!, GPSr:Batteries low Abbey:WHAT! not now!!! I take it back, I won't trade you in! GPSr: --------------- Abbey:Nooooooooooo!
And so with no GPSr (and no map [:)] ) I had no idea were I was going, but thankfully after that little episode, I found a garage and bought some batteries for the GPSr (and chocolate for me [:)] ) and I was on my way again. Phew! I found the cache site with no further problems. The driving range was busy today. Quickly located the cache. Nice sized container. Thanks for the adventure!
TNLN. SL. TFTC

2010-05-09T19:00:00Z : Found it by Spark_ie
Nice hide, found it no problems [:)] I think it's better to come from the West to this location... ! TFTC, Spark_ie

2010-04-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by Sookmeister
Found late at night in good company!
TFTC :-)

2010-04-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by Shailaja
Nice clue - was easy to find, even in the dark. With Toffee Man, Sookmeister, Blue Jay 59 and Effie. TFTC Shailaja

wpt.name: GC2244G
wpt.desc: Done Sink by Lahtac, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache is in reference to the Dunsink Observatory, which is an astronomical observatory established in approximately 1785 near the city of Dublin, Ireland. Stroll up to the entrance gate to view the Observatory building itself. Location is N 53.23.281, W 06.20.237
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Historical Values Patrick A. Wayman's book "Dunsink Observatory 1785-1985" gives some historical latitude and longitude measurements for Dunsink. The figures quoted for longitude are: • Rev.
